abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings show a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Regardless of success,
            some lessons underline the following. The lack of a robust
            monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system, and its
            dependent baseline data, deprive otherwise good projects, of
            the possibility of being systematically reviewed, and its
            performance judged accordingly. The Bank's experience
            should be used to create such an M&E system,
            particularly in the case of legal reform projects. In
            addition, the establishment of Legal Advisory Groups with a
            broad range of institutional representation, proved
            important for targeted uses of grant resources, based on the
            country's legislative agenda. However, the
            establishment of a Training Advisory Group would have
            benefited training in the efforts for sharing useful
            experiences, develop reformed law curricula and teaching
            methodologies, as well as from international
            consultants' experiences. This leads to the issue of
            Bank staff managing legal reform projects, who require
            access to a comprehensive database of experts across legal
            disciplines, upon which they can rely for help and advice.
            This is a structural problem in the Bank's system which
            needs to be addressed for the Bank to offer first rate
            international experience on complex legal reform activities.
            Finally, it is suggested that Projects building
            institutional capacity, and utilizing existing government
            structures for implementation, have a greater chance of
            success, as opposed to projects that rely on independent
            stand-alone implementation units.

18152584.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18152584.theme: Legal services,Legal institutions for a market economy,Law reform

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Law Reform Project will
            assist China in improving the legal framework to support
            economic reform by: (a) strengthening the preparation of
            economic legislation in priority areas; (b) enhance training
            methods, curricula and opportunities for law teachers, legal
            practitioners and legal, judicial and other government
            personnel in the theory and practice of the new legal
            framework; and (c) strengthening the key legal institutions
            responsible for legislation and the implementation of
            economic laws. The project will consist of three parts:
            sub-projects to support preparation of legislation;
            sub-projects to support legal training; and institutional support.
